abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Plasticity related gene 1 encodes a cerebral neuron-specific synaptic transmembrane protein that modulates hippocampal excitatory transmission on glutamatergic neurons. In mice, homozygous Prg1-deficiency results in juvenile epilepsy. Screening a cohort of 18 patients with infantile spasms (West syndrome), we identified one patient with a heterozygous mutation in the highly conserved third extracellular phosphatase domain (p.T299S). The functional relevance of this mutation was verified by <jats:italic>in-utero</jats:italic> electroporation of a mutant <jats:italic>Prg1</jats:italic> construct into neurons of <jats:italic>Prg1</jats:italic>-knockout embryos, and the subsequent inability of hippocampal neurons to rescue the knockout phenotype on the single cell level. Whole exome sequencing revealed the index patient to additionally harbor a novel heterozygous <jats:italic>SCN1A</jats:italic> variant (p.N541S) that was inherited from her healthy mother. Only the affected child carried both heterozygous <jats:italic>PRG1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>SCN1A</jats:italic> mutations. The aggravating effect of <jats:italic>Prg1</jats:italic>-haploinsufficiency on the epileptic phenotype was verified using the kainate-model of epilepsy. Double heterozygous <jats:italic>Prg1</jats:italic><jats:sup>-/+</jats:sup>|<jats:italic>Scn1a<jats:sup>wt/p.R1648H</jats:sup></jats:italic>mice exhibited higher seizure susceptibility than either wildtype, <jats:italic>Prg1</jats:italic><jats:sup>-/+</jats:sup>, or <jats:italic>Scn1a<jats:sup>wt/p.R1648H</jats:sup></jats:italic> littermates. Our study provides evidence that <jats:italic>PRG1</jats:italic>-mutations have a potential modifying influence on <jats:italic>SCN1A</jats:italic>-related epilepsy in humans.</jats:p>
title: Mutant Plasticity Related Gene 1 (PRG1) acts as a potential modifier in SCN1A related epilepsy
